Con el dinero del préstamo, Norma comprará fierros, bolsas de cemento y ladrillos para empezar la construcción de las primeras paredes de su nuevo hogar, para eso, Héctor tendrá que distribuir su tiempo para construirla y no descuidar sus sembríos.
texts.en:
She may appear weak but 40-year-old Norma has a secure and entrepreneurial personality.  Norma is married to 48-year-old Héctor and has seven children, only four of whom still live with her.  They live together in their own home, in the indigenous community of Pucharini.

Norma has been working the land since she was a girl, growing coffee, bananas and annatto, products which have provided both her and her family with the support they need up to now.  They have two and a half plots of land and prioritize the planting of coffee.  Héctor, Norma's husband, farms full time whilst Norma works for a coffee packing company which pays her a monthly salary.  This makes her more income.  As if that weren't enough, Norma also sells food from her home on Sundays.  "Despite the fact that my plots of land are small, I obtain three 120kg sacks of coffee from them.  We sell the coffee by the can.  Each can weighs 2 kilos and the price right now is 6 soles.  There are months when we sell for double that if we agree on it", explains Norma.

In the future, Norma would like to live in a home with more comforts and more concise and hard-wearing infrastructure.  For example, she will have sewerage service installed and put in a sink as a priority.  In order to achieve this, she will continue working as she has up to now.  With your help, Norma will be able to obtain her fourth loan from MFP.  She pledges to make her repayments on time each month as she has been doing, together with the other members of her community bank.  Norma feels comfortable being part of her community bank because everybody cooperates and they know how to organize themselves.  Norma will use her loan money to buy iron, bags of cement and bricks so that she can start building the first walls of her new home.  In order to do this, Héctor will have to divide his time so that he can build the house without neglecting his crops.

loans.use: to buy cement, bricks and iron

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet lives in Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (including a niece). Janet's business is a retail shop. She has been in this business for two years, and she works seven days out of every week. Janet sells household products in her retail shop and also generates additional income by selling secondhand clothes. Janet has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of rice, maize flour, sugar and boxes of soap. The main business challenges for Janet include seasonality and ever increasing prices of commodities in Uganda. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked shop and also to become a wholesaler. Janet lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family, rent for her business premises and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of rice, maize flour, sugar and boxes of soap.

loans.name: Sadith  Esther

texts.es: Sadith se dedica a la fabricación de productos artesanales como manillas, tejidos, pedrería  entre otras manualidades, que ofrece a sus clientes  en un punto de venta. Sus principales materias primas son el coco, las semillas, los hilos, y el totumo, un fruto  que crece en Colombia, es de fuerte corteza  que se endurece cuando está maduro. Su arte forma parte de una tradición, usada en   la época precolombina, cuando  los indígenas mocanás que habitaron el centro y sur del Atlántico, utilizaban esta corteza para hacer vasijas -llamadas totumas- y cantimploras en las que almacenaban leche y agua y para uso  decorativo como lo hace Sadith.  Desde el año 2004 cuando estudiaba su bachillerato, su cónyuge le enseñó este oficio, en la actualidad ambos trabajan en su punto de ventas,  ubicado en una esquina muy  concurrida, y cerca de un centro comercial, lo cual hace posible que sus ventas cada día aumenten mas, por eso trabajan sin descanso de lunes a domingo de 10:00 a m  a 9:00 p.m. Su competencia es alta pero tiene un buen surtido y esto es justamente lo que atrae a sus clientes, además de su buen trato con ellos. En la actualidad está aplicando a su primer credikiva y también primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el comprará, hilos, piedras, acero, totumos semillas, al por mayor y de contado, con lo cual obtendrá muchos descuentos por volumen de compra y por hacerlo de contado.
texts.en:
Sadith makes crafts such as bracelets, weavings, and the other handicrafts that she sells to customers at her stand. Her main raw materials are coconuts, seeds, thread and totumos, a fruit that grows in Colombia with a tough peel that hardens when it's ripe. 

Her art is part of a tradition, dating from the pre-Columbian era. The indigenous Mocanás who inhabited the central and Atlantic south parts of the country, used these gourds to make dishes called totumas, canteens in which they stored milk and water, and for decorative purposes, as Sadith does.

Since 2004, when she was studying for her diploma, her partner taught her this skill. Currently both work at her stand, located at a busy corner near a shopping mall, which enables her to increase her sales every day. That's why she works tirelessly from Monday to Sunday, from 10:00am to 9:00pm. 

Her competition is intense, but she has a good stock, and this is precisely what attracts her customers; besides how well she treats them. At present, she is applying for her first Credikiva, which is also her first loan from the Fundación Santo Domingo. With the money, she will buy thread, stones, metal, totumos and seeds at wholesale, for cash, so that she gets a lot of discounts for volume purchase and for paying cash.

loans.use: To buy threads, stones, steel, totumos, and seeds at wholesale, for cash.

loans.name: Mapengo W.g Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mapengo W.G Group in Western Kenya! Beatrice is the facilitator of the Mapengo W.G group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Beatrice takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Beatrice had a good maize yield, harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest 15 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Beatrice will educate her children and pay back her loans.

In 2012, the members of Mapengo W.G group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Beatrice with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ingredients.

loans.name: Lydia Susan

texts.en: Lydia, 32 years old, is married and has a two-year-old son. She describes herself as a visionary woman. She runs a retail store and sells detergents, cooking fat, sugar, rice, etc.  She has been involved in this business for two years.  Lydia faces a challenge of insufficient funds for expanding her business.  She will be using the loan KES 20,000 to buy two bags of rice, one bag of sugar, and five cartons of cooking fat.  Her hopes and dreams for the next five years is to run a supermarket.

loans.use: buy rice, sugar and cooking fat

loans.name: Haniya

texts.en:
Haniya is a 47-year-old housewife. Working from home, Haniya has been fixing the edges of special men’s covers called “Shmagh”, by adding small balls made of wool. She also does embroidery on women’s scarves, head covers and dresses. It has been two years since she started officially and by doing this work she has been able to help improve her family's living standards.
Now Haniya has applied for a loan to buy more wool and other material to accessorize dresses.

loans.use: to buy more wool and other material to accessorize dresses.

loans.name: Vivogbe Group

texts.fr: Le groupe VIVOGBE est composé de quatre personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. Félicité Afiavi, la représentante du groupe (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 43 ans est mariée à un menuisier nommé Félicien. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. En dehors de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à sa charge. Félicité Afiavi vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les différentes charges de ménage sont supportées par Félicité Afiavi et son mari. Félicité Afiavi a très peu fréquenté l’école. Depuis vingt un ans, Félicité Afiavi vend des condiments et des vivres à son domicile ce qui lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Félicité Afiavi s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Félicité Afiavi sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe VIVOGBE un crédit auprès de ALIDé

loans.use: Acheter des condiments et des vivres

loans.name: Yabo

texts.fr: Yabo âgée de 39 ans n'a pas fréquenté l’école. Yabo est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Laurent. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Yabo vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari et assure ensemble avec son mari les différentes charges du ménage. Yabo vend des parfum depuis quatorze ans. De façon secondaire, Yabo vend aussi des pommades et des poudres ; ce qui lui permet de contribuer à l'éducation et à l'entretien des enfants. Yabo s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. La clientèle de Yabo devient de plus en plus grandissante. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d'affaire et son revenu, Yabo sollicite une sixième fois l’appui financier de ALIDé. Les crédits reçus antérieurement ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des parfums et des pommades.

loans.name: Ignacia

texts.en:
Ignacia works hard to support her family. Ignacia is married and has a selling dried fish business in the Philippines.

Ignacia requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Ignacia has been in this business for 9 years now.

In the future, Ignacia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sali

texts.en: Sali S. lives in Tzar Kaloian, near Razgrad and as most of men in the town works as a constructor. Eight years ago he starts his parallel farming business when he rents a cow shed and starts to breed three cows. Now there are 12 cows in his farm. Sali continues his work as a constructor ad he has hired a worker to take care of his cows. The loan amount thet he applies for is $ 1200 and the loan aid is to buy two more cows.

loans.use: To buy two more cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Grace would like to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Pablina

texts.en:
Pablina is a 42-year-old married mother of nine. She is one of those hardworking women who has moved ahead with growing and selling corn and corn bread, one of the tradition products of her town. With the help of her husband she has raised all of her children, the oldest of which is 22 and is in his final year at agricultural school. Another one of her kids is in his first year at a private college studying law. The youngest is 5 years old. Even though they're in school, all of the children lend a hand to their mother when they can because they know it helps generate a little more income and cover expenses. Pablina is a very enterprising woman who does not know pain or fatigue. She works day and night all week long so that her children don't lack anything. She says her children are her hope for the future. Pablina plans to use the loan to construct two booths where she can sell her product so she can increase her sales and achieve a better life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunter

Pablina tiene 42 años y es casada con 9 hijos. Ella es una D. las tantas mujeres trabajadoras que ha salido adelante con la fabricación y venta D. miel y pan D. miel, que es uno D. los tradicionales productos D. Itá. Con la ayuda D. su esposo ha criado a todos sus hijos, el mayor D. ellos tiene 22 años y está cursando el último año en una escuela agrícola.Otra D. sus hijas está en el primer año D. una universidad privada cursando la carrera D. derecho y el menor D. todos tiene 5 años. Todos sus hijos han aprendido el oficio y aunque continúan estudiando, no dejan D. darles una mano a su madre, ya que ellos consideran que con eso ayudan a generar un poco más D. dinero para ayudarles con los gastos. Pablina es una mujer muy emprendedora, no conoce D. dolor ni cansancio ya que trabaja noche y día durante toda la semana para que D. esta forma no les falte nada a sus hijos. Ella misma afirma que sus hijos son su esperanza para el futuro. Planea utilizar el crédito para construir dos casillas más en donD. exhibirá sus productos a fin D. aumentar sus ventas y lograr una vida más digna para toda su familia.

loans.use: Construction of two booths to sell her products

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa Q. Vda. De Bautista lives in the Sajama area of the city of El Alto with her children and her 9 grandchildren.

She has been a Pro Mujer partner for 5 years. Teresa handcrafts sweaters from wool and then sells her products in the streets of the southern part of the city of La Paz.

With her first Pro Mujer loan, she was able to increase her inventory, which in turn later allowed her to acquire a sewing machine. The machine has allowed her to substantially increase her income. Currently Teresa is making both wool sweaters and baby's clothing (baby's sweaters/jackets). She needs capital to be able to buy raw materials with which to fulfill existing demand, and at the same time plans to expand the variety of products that she offers.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Teresa Q. Vda. De Bautista, vive en la zona Sajama de la ciudad de El Alto, en compañía de sus hijos y sus 9 nietos.

Socia de Pro Mujer hace 5 años, Teresa se dedica a la confección de chompas de lana, mismas que comercializa de forma ambulante en la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz .

Con su primer desembolso, logra incrementar su mercadería, para posteriormente adquirir una máquina de costura, lo que le permite mejorar sus ingresos sustancialmente.

Actualmente Teresa paralelamente a la confección de chompas de lana se dedica a confeccionar ropa de bebe (chambritas), y necesita de más capital para poder comprar materia prima que le permita satisfacer la demanda existente y del mismo modo aumentar la variedad de sus productos.

loans.use: Buy raw materials with which to meet existing demand and offer a wider variety of products

loans.name: Lucía

texts.en:
Lucia Irene C. is a member of the Snow White association in Villa Adela, city of El Alto. Her main occupation is the sale of lingerie and baby clothes in the various street fairs and open air markets of El Alto. She has only been doing this for the past 2 years, as prior to that time she dedicated herself full time to taking care of her young son. When her son's needs grew and she didn't have enough money to cover expenses, Lucia went off to work.

Today, Lucia needs working capital to invest in more inventory for the upcoming holiday season. She would like to stock up before the prices she pays go up and cut into her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucia Irene C., pertenece a la asociación Blanca Nieves de Villa Adela en la ciudad de El Alto. Lucía se dedica a la venta de lencería, ropa interior y ropa de bebé, de forma ambulante en las ferias y mercados de las distintas zonas de la ciudad de El Alto. Son solamente dos años que se dedica a esta actividad, ya que antes de esto, Lucía solo se dedicaba al cuidado de su pequeño hijo, pero al ver que las necesidades del menor continuamente aumentaban, y el dinero no alcanzaba, tuvo que comenzar a trabajar. Hoy en día Lucia precisa de capital para poder incrementar la variedad de su mercadería, aprovechando de aprovisionarse para las fiestas de fin de año, ya que en esa temporada los precios suben y la ganancia se reduce.

loans.use: To invest in more inventory for the upcoming holiday season

loans.name: Maria Pedro

texts.pt:
Maria is single, but she lives a man with whom she has 5 children. Maria's children are studying - some in secondary school and others in primary school. Maria's partner is not employed, and lives from small jobs to support his family. Maria entered the program in 2006. She does her business in a market. She and her family live in the Town of Maxixe. With the earnings, she wants to help her husband with the household epenses. In the future, she is planning to fix up her residence. Maria's children are currently studying.

Translated from Portuguese by a Kiva volunteer.

Maria e solteira mas vive com um homem com quem tem 5 filhos. Os filhos de Maria estao a estudar alguns no ensino secundario basico e outros no ensino primario. O marido de Maria nao esta empregado. Vive de pequenos negocios para o sustento de sua familia. Maria entrou para o Programa em 2006. Ela faz o seu negocio num mercado. Ela e sua familia vivem no Municipio da Maxixe. Com os rendimentos ela quer ajudar o marido nas despesas da casa. No futuro pensa reabilitar a sua residencia.Os filhos de Maria estao a estudar.

loans.use: Maria wants to use the money for the purchase of plastic buckets and pans to sell.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosita is a member of the community bank Atenas Portillanas. She lives in the housing development Pedro Portillo in the Callería district in the department (region) of Ucayali. She is 53 years old and the mother of 7 children, all independent now. She is separated, but her income doesn't cover her household expenses. As a result, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos, for 300 soles (Peruvian currency) , Rosita decided to invest in a seamstress shop making clothes for women, men and children.

Currently Rosita along with her children are doing well with the sales of the clothing she makes. Every day she has to sew 2 or 3 dresses, since she works on order. To fill her orders she works into the wee hours of the night in order to meet her commitments to her clients.

This loan for 1900 soles, which she will repay in 6 months, will buy 200 soles in cloth, 20 in elastic, 20 in lace, 20 in satin ribbon and 20 in thread.

Rosita is a very enterprising woman with a tremendous desire to get ahead. Thanks to those characteristics and Manuela Ramos she is able to work managing her own business and her own clients. She feels very happy and proud.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Rosita pertenece al Banco Comunal Atenas Portillanas, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Pedro Portillo Mz. C Lt. 02 del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 53 años de edad, es madre de 7 hijos todos independientes, es separada, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar, es así que Rosita, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, decide invertir en un taller de costura de ropas para damas, caballeros y niños.

Actualmente Rosita, junto a sus hijos, salen adelante con la venta de la ropa que confeccionan. Diariamente tiene que coser de 2 a 3 vestidos, ya que trabaja con pedidos, para eso ella se desvela hasta altas horas de la noche para terminar su último pedido y cumplir con sus clientas.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,900, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará S/. 200 en telas, S/. 20 en elásticos, S/. 20 en blondas, S/. 20 cintas satinadas y S/. 20 en hilos.

Rosita es una señora muy emprendedora, con muchas ganas de salir adelante, es así que gracias a Manuela Ramos puede trabajar manejando su propio negocio y sus propios clientes. Se siente muy feliz y orgullosa.

loans.use: Purchase of  materials (cloth, elastic, lace, satin ribbon and thread)

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata J. is a 30-year-old married mother of four children. 

Fatmata came up with the idea of selling food items in the village where access to these items was difficult. She has now been in business for four years. She sells onions, tomato pest, chicken stocks, etc., and has saved the village women from traveling to either Kabala town or a trading center located 3 kilometers away. With previous loans, she increased her stock and now would like to expand more.

loans.use: She wants to build her business by increasing her stock.

loans.name: Osimjon

texts.ru:
Osimjon M. is married and has three children. He manages a general food store, where he sells goods supplied to him by his friends. He rents the store space and, since during winter the trading was slow, he needs to take out a loan to purchase additional goods for his store. His friends have advised him to turn to Microinvest for money. Osimjon has already taken out one loan to purchase more goods and it now applying for another one in order to expand his inventory.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Осимджон женат имеет троих детей. Его товар привозят друзья. Его товар состоит из продуктов питания. Он арендует магазин, ему нужны были деньги, его друзья посоветовали обратиться в Микроинвест. Так как после зимы торговля шла очень медленно, и ассортимента товара был не так уж велик. По совету друзей он получил кредит, он приобрел товар. Теперь ему необходимо расширить и увеличить свой ассортимент.

loans.use: Expanding inventory

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria has belonged to Banco Comunal Ayni II for four months.

Victoria is married, is 57 years old and has two children. Along with her husband, Victoria owns a chicken restaurant named “La Merced,” which is located in her home on a central street of the city of Ayacucho. For two years, the specialty of her restaurant has been chicken breast and grilled chicken. With the loan that she will obtain, she plans to increase the capacity of her business for the Semana Santa festivities that are approaching.

Victoria needs a loan of 2,000 soles which will be invested in the purchase of tables and chairs.

Victoria’s dream is to increase her business’ capital, help her children in everything, improve her business and open another restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Victoria pertenece al Banco Comunal “Ayni II” hace 4 meses.

Victoria es casada, tiene 57 años y 2 hijos, Victoria junto a su esposo tienen una pollería llamada “La Merced”, ubicada en su casa, en una calle céntrica D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. La especialidad D. su restaurante es pollo a la braza y a la parrilla, actividad que realiza hace 2 años. Con el préstamo que obtendrá tiene proyectado implementar su negocio para tener más capacidad D. atención en la fiesta D. Semana Santa que se aproxima.

Victoria necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. mesas y sillas.

Los sueños D. Victoria son incrementar el capital D. su negocio, ayudar a sus hijos en todo, ampliar su negocio y tener una sucursal.

loans.use: Victoria needs a loan of 2,000 soles which will be invested in the purchase of tables and chairs.

loans.name: Mwanamiraji

texts.en:
Mwanamiraji is married with 8 children, aged 14-30. Mwanamiraji sells chickens, a business that she began in 2007. She works every day from 7 am to 9 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chickens for her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for her business.

loans.name: Naygir

texts.es:
Doña Naygir is a member of “Banco Comunal Las Flores del Paraíso”, located in Jr Apurimac 372, District of Calleria of the Department of Ucayali. She is 38 years old and the mother of 2 daughters. Her husband is a chauffeur, but his income is not sufficient to support his family, and therefore, with a previous first loan received from Manuela Ramos, S/.300, doña Naygir decided to invest in a business, buying and selling beauty products. Presently she has a business of promotion and investment in beauty products; she gets up at 7 a.m. to prepare breakfast for her daughters and husband and then she works in her office until 5 p.m. With this loan of S/.1,700 ($625) to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy showcases to increase her stock as well as more cosmetics. Naygir feels as a successful entrepreneur remembering how her income was poor when she started her business and with limitations to support her family, but with hard work and effort she has moved ahead and if it has not been for Manuela Ramos, this would not have been possible.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Naygir pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Flores del Paraíso, ubicado en el Jr Apurimac 372, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años y es madre de 2 hijas, su esposo es chofer, pero los ingresos con los que cuenta no alcanzan para mantener a su familia, es así que Naygir con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un negocio de compra y venta de productos de belleza. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de promoción e inversión de productos de belleza, para lo cual se levanta a las 7 am, para preparar el desayuno de sus hijas y de su esposo y luego se dedica a la atención de su oficina hasta las 5 pm. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará: vitrinas para ampliar su negocio y también comprará mas cosméticos. Naygir se siente una mujer emprendedora y con mucho éxito recuerda que cuando empezó su negocio sus ganancias eran muy pocas y aun tenia limitaciones para apoyar a su familia pero le costó trabajo y esfuerzo lograr lo que hasta ahora ha obtenido pero dice que si no fuera por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos nada de esto hubiera sido así.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to increase sales.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
HILDA is a mother with 2 children who are her “motor of life”, who motivate her to work and increase her desire to progress as a farmer so as to improve the quality of life in her home. And here we find her in her fields of corn that are ready to harvest now that the growing season is over. Because of her wish to start planting peas she is asking for a loan, mainly for the purchase of pea seeds, since she has observed a great demand for this vegetable in her city market.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

HILDA, es madre de 2 hijos quienes son su motor de vida que la impulsa a trabajar y a incrementar sus deseos de progresar como agricultora a fin de mejorar la calidad de vida dentro de su hogar.Y la encontramos en sus terrenos de cultivo de maíz que está a punto de cosechar ya que se termina la temporada del cultivo y frente a su deseo de iniciar el sembrío de arveja, está solicitando un préstamo básicamente para la compra de semillas de arveja ya que ha observado la gran demanda de este vegetal en el mercado de su ciudad.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds, manure and natural fertilizers

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia baji, the wife of G. F., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 35 years. She owns a three-room mud house and is the mother of three sons. Her elder son is 22 years old and finished his education until the 5th standard (grade). Her next son is 12 years old and in the 5th standard, while her youngest son is 8 years old and in the 2nd standard. She is applying for a loan on behalf of her eldest son, a driver by profession who wants to buy and drive his own auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled vehicle).

She is joined in her loan group by three other members: Shakeela baji wants a loan to expand her electric shop; Irshad baji wishes to buy an auto-rickshaw; Farzana baji wants a loan to expand her food business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Ophelia

texts.en:
Ophelia E. sells sugar cane and sugar cane syrup. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Ophelia and her 4 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim, 34 years old, a married man with no children yet, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. He is the proud owner of a small gas station on the village's main road. He needs a loan in the amount of US$ 1,200 to pay for gas pump maintenance and to purchase a stock of motor oil. This is the second time that Ibrahim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Maintenance of the gas station and purchase of motor oil

loans.name: Gulam Mohammad

texts.en:
Gulam M. is a hard-working businessman and father who has run a furniture-making shop for the past 15 years. He now employs five workers. His business is doing well and he has the opportunity to sell his furniture in distant locations such as other cities, as well as China and Iran.

To make this possible, he is applying for an 18-month loan which he will use to expand his business and begin selling his products in new markets.

Gulam M. wants to thank Kiva and all his lenders.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Denia

texts.es:
Con sus 55 años, 8 de ellos con su tienda, la labor que desempeña la señora Denia es admirable desde todo punto de vista. Porque ha tenido que ingeniárselas para poder darle a sus hijos lo mejor que pueda acorde con sus posibilidades, por lo cual ha venido desarrollando un sinnúmero de actividades: venta de salchipapa, lavado de ropa a domicilio, etc., es decir, todo en afán de la crianza de sus 4 hijos (aunque 2 de ellos ya mayores: de 29 y 24 años; los otros 2, menores, de 18 y 14 años, a quienes les solventa su educación). A pesar del tremendo esfuerzo en más de 25 años como madre, aún no puede terminar de construir su pequeña casa, yendo esto en detrimento de la calidad de vida de su familia y productividad de los negocios que expende desde y en casa, anhelando la finalización de su casa como tal.

Con ánimos de implementarse de insumos necesarios para afrontar la venidera campaña navideña, la señora Denia necesita de 300 soles, lo que le serviría como sustento a su capital en pos de mercadería y optimizando su nivel de ganancias.
texts.en:
Being 55 years old, owning her store for 8 of them, the work that Mrs. Denia does is admirable from all points of view. Because she has had to manage in order to give her children the best that she could according to her possibilities, she has been developing in a number of activities: selling kebab, laundry services in the homes, etc., in other words, anything she needs to do to raise her 4 children ( even though 2 of them are already grown, 29 and 24 years old, and the other two are 18 and 14 years old, for whom she pays their education) In spite of her tremendous efforts during 25 years of being a mother, she still cannot complete the construction of her small home, this being a detriment to the quality of life of her family and the productivity of the businesses that she runs from and in her home. She yearns to finish her house such as it is. With the desire to obtain the necessary supplies to be able to face the upcoming Christmas season, Mrs. Denia needs $100 USD, which will provide the capital for merchandise and will increase her level of income.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To be able to count on more funds and acquire more products at better prices which will increase her profits.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha tiene 35 años, vive con sus 2 hijos. Se dedica a la agricultura de manera independiente desde hace 20 años, siembra productos de su zona, principalmente la papa, también cría animales como vacas, y ovejas, de esta manera puede enfrentar los momentos de escasez económica mientras espera la cosecha, ya que sólo se pueden ver los frutos una vez que se cosechan, por lo que Martha ahora, vende animales todos los días viernes en la feria ganadera de su localidad, entonces vuelve a comprar otros para luego revender. Es la primera vez que Martha solicita un préstamo en MFP, se compromete a  ser puntual en la devolución del préstamo.  El dinero será utilizado en la compra de más animales, dos ovejas, también un saco de abono, ya que tiene listo un saco de semilla de papa para ser sembrada en una área de terreno.
texts.en:
Martha is 35 and lives with her two children. She has worked as an independent farmer for 20 years, she grows local crops, mainly potato, she also raises livestock such as cattle and sheep, this way she can face the bad economic moments while she awaits for harvest, because you can only see the rewards once the crops have been harvested, that’s why now Martha sells livestock every Friday at the local livestock fair, she buys more and then re-sells. This is the first time that Martha requests a loan through Microfinanzas Prisma, she commits to be punctual with the repayments. The money will be used to buy more livestock; two sheep and a sack of fertilizer because she has a piece of land ready for potato seeds.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and sheep

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam Ouologeme a 44 ans, mère de 7 enfants elle vit chez son époux dans une famille polygame avec ses enfants dans le quartier wala wala de la préfecture de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Issue d’une famille de commerçants, Mariam a été très vite initiée aux activités génératrices de revenues (car ses parents n’ont jamais voulu qu’elle fréquente l’école). Après une longue phase d’apprentissage auprès de sa mère, elle décida de se spécialiser dans le commerce de condiments alimentaires depuis maintenant 20 ans. La demande de la clientèle est très importante car elle est trés  connue dans le secteur et presque toutes les femmes de son entourage font leurs achats chez elle. 
Afin d’augmenter son étalage, elle se tourna vers l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya de cela  3 ans. Avec une expérience de 4 prêts en solidaire  (prêt de groupe) bien remboursés ,elle est à son 2eme prêt en individuel dont le 1er s’est terminé sans difficulté. 
Madame Mariam compte acheter, 2kg de fièfiè, 50kg d’oignons, 3kg de laye, 2 sachets de vermicelles, 2kg de poivres, des légumes  et autres.. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Koutiala et  vend ses condiments dans  à son domicile à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes, au comptant ou à crédit.  Espérant générer un bénéfice de 60.000FCFA, Madame Mariam Ouologuème compte les utiliser pour le  remboursement des intérêts du prêt, payer  les frais de scolarité de ses  enfants et  investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrice de revenus.
Mariam est à la recherche d’une place au   marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariam Ouologuème is a 44-year-old mother of 7 who lives with her husband in a polygamous family with his children in the Wala Wala neighborhood in the Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Coming from a family of merchants, Mariam was introduced early on to the business world (since her parents never wanted her to go to school). After a long period of training with her mother, she decided to specialize in the sale of seasonings, which she has been doing for 20 years. The demand of her clientele is significant, as she is very well known in her area and almost all of the women in her circle buy from her. In order to increase her goods, she turned to microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. After having repaid 4 group loans, she is on her 2nd individual loan; her first one was repaid without incident. Mrs. Mariam plans to buy 2 kg of “fièfiè,” 50 kg of onions, 3 kg of garlic, 2 packets of vermicelli, 2 kg of pepper, vegetables, etc. She stocks up at the Koutiala market and sells her seasonings from home mostly to women for cash or credit. Hoping to earn a profit of 60,000 CFA francs, Mrs. Mariam Ouologuème plans to use this to repay the loan, pay for her children’s’ schooling, and invest the rest in other businesses. Mariam is looking for a spot at the Koutiala market.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy seasonings

loans.name: Gertrude's Group

texts.en:
Gertrude N. is the leader of her group and a business lady with a retail shop as her business. She is a married lady with 5 children and she cares for one cousin. The loans have been so helpful especially now that her husband has two wives and his attention towards his children and family is all divided.

Gertrude uses her loans to buy more products for the shop like sugar, cooking oil, flour, etc., and as a result the profits and savings help to run her home. She is also a farmer on a small scale and this food enables her to save the money she would have used on buying food to pay school fees and clothe her children. She needs another loan for her shop, to expand it.

loans.use: expanding the inventory of her small shop

loans.name: Purisima

texts.en:
Purisima is a fish vendor in the public market of Tumauini, Isabela. She has been in this business for ten years and still hopes to improve her business through growth. She would like to borrow a loan of $150 (PHP6,000.00) that she will use to increase her inventory of fish. Through the support of her family, Purisima was always inspired in her business undertakings though sometimes, sales were not good.

She is married to Benito, a farmer and a councilor in their village. Ybanag dialect is the common language in the area. They were blessed with six children: Junior, 37; Francisca, 34; Gil, 31; Romy, 30; Jocelyn, 28; Julie, 26. Five of them were high school graduates but only their youngest, Julie, completed her college degree.

loans.use: Increase her fish inventory for resale at the market

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
Queen has been a businesswoman in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 232. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Queen is 33 years old, widowed, and has four children: ages 15, 13, 9, and 7.

loans.use: To buy more items for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Nargis Ghulam Mustafa Group

texts.en:
Nargis baji is the wife of G. M., who has lived in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan, for the last 8 years. She is the mother of three sons. All are getting an education at a local school. Nargis baji operates a business sewing clothes. She learned this art from her husband, who operates a tailoring center in the community. He has been in this profession for the last 4 years. People come to him to stitch their clothes. He charges $2 for normal stitching, and $3 for designer clothes. Nargis baji is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for her husband’s tailoring center.

Nargis baji is the group leader of another three women from her area. Anwari baji requests a loan to buy mason's tools. Rukhsana baji requests a loan to buy a welding machine. Naseem akhtar baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina K., 29, is married with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and the general public 4 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Sina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase plantsprayer, chemical, knives and fertilizers for plantation business.

loans.name: Apolinario Gaudencio

texts.en: Apolinario A., a 37-year-old fish vendor, is married with two kids. He is a resident of Aloran, Misamis Occidental.  The family's main source of income is his fish-vending business.  Recently he applied for a loan from Paglaum for additional capital for his business. If the business grows in the future, he plans to expand the business and buy a fish car so he can cater to more consumers not only in the town of Aloran but in the province of Misamis Occidental as well.

loans.use: Capital for his fish-selling business

loans.name: Paul's Group

texts.en:
Z. Paul is the leader of Kwesitukira group in Lugazi. He is a friendly and hard-working man with a farming business, selling produce mostly from his farm. During the 10 years that he has run this business, he has been faced with a few challenges, like the high transport costs to deliver his produce to his customers, and the high cost of purchasing the produce when he does not have enough to supply to his customers.

This is his 14th loan from his group and he is able to make a profit of 200,000 UGX in a month. Paul has a dream of buying his own truck to transport his goods, as well as having an educated family. He is a 41-year-old married man with 10 children; the eldest is 21 years old and in school. He also cares for 10 dependents, some of whom are orphans. He requests a loan to purchase produce like cassava and sweet potatoes for his business.

loans.use: Buy more produce (cassava and sweet potatoes) to sell

loans.name: Lino Salmeron

texts.es: Lino S. Z. es un señor de 45 años de edad. el tiene 4 hijos pero 2 de ellos viven por cuenta propia y 2 están bajo su cuido. la actividad económica a la que se dedica don Lino es a la venta y compra de cerdos, además vende leña en su casa de habitación. empezó su trabajo desde hace 12 años cuando vivía en una situación caótica y ya sus hijos empezaban a crecer necesitados de una mejor alimentación y al encontrarse en esta situación decidió empezar a picar leña y salía a venderla en su pequeña carreta , fueron momentos duro pues muchas veces el dinero se gastaba en la alimentación de su familia. hasta que su esposa le dio la idea de la crianza de cerdos, con la ayuda de ella pudieron salir adelante, de esta manera Lino obtuvo mas ingresos y empezó a pedir financiamientos para comprarse otro buey pues el anterior ya estaba muy viejo y temía que se le muriera pronto y no tuviese un repuesto; el deseo de don Lino es preparar a sus hijos para que no sean simples leñadores y criadores de cerdo como el lo es pues un padre desea  lo mejor para sus hijos, de esta forma Lino solicita un préstamo confiando en que le será otorgado ya que el necesita invertir en la compra de cerdos al por mayor para obtener un mejor precio.
texts.en:
Lino S. Z. is a 45-year-old man who has four children. Two of them live on their own and two are with him. He makes a living selling and buying pigs. He also sells firewood from his home. He began his work twelve years ago when he was living in a chaotic situation and his kids started needing things like, better nutrition. Finding himself in this situation, he decided to begin collecting firewood and to go out and sell it in a small cart. They were difficult times since the money was often spent on feeding his family, until his wife gave him the idea of raising pigs. With her help, they have been able to get ahead by doing this. Lino started earning more and began to ask for loans to buy another donkey, since the former one was very old and he was afraid that it would die soon and he wouldn’t know what to do. Mr. Lino would like to educate his children so they are not simple firewood salesmen and pig farmers like he is. A father wants the best for his kids and this is why Lino is requesting a loan, believing he will receive it, since he needs to invest in buying wholesale pigs so he can get a better price.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: El Milagro Group 3

texts.en:
Sandra is part of a solidarity group called El Milagro, or The Miracle. This group lives in the small agricultural town of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic and has been together since 2006. This tight-knit group of friends has helped each other grow their businesses over the years and they are seeking another loan to further their success.

Sandra is the 37-year-old mother of two (aged 11 and 4) and owns her own salon. With this loan, she hopes to buy supplies such as shampoo and nail polish so that she can serve more customers. With the extra income, she hopes to save up so that she can send her children to the university and fulfill her dream of seeing them become successful professionals. 

Sandra and the whole El Milagro group appreciate the opportunities micro loans have given them and they hope to continue their success.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her salon

loans.name: Akramjon

texts.en:
S. Akramjon is 24 years old. He is married and has two small children. Akramjon has a small restaurant where he sells breakfast, lunch and dinner. Prior to opening his own business, he worked at a restaurant where he learned the ins and outs of the trade. When Akramjon first started his business he only opened to sell breakfast because he worked at night. Once his place became more popular he was able to dedicate his whole time to the business. Akramjon wants this loan so he may invest in tables, chairs and utensils. He is asking for $1500 USD. With this money, Akramjon will be able to expand his business and to earn more. The well being of this family is in your hands. Contribute to the growth of his business and they will be grateful.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase tables, chairs and utensils for expanding his cafe.

loans.name: Frankline Awino

texts.en:
Frankline owns and operates a small restaurant kiosk (called “hotels” in Kenya) where she makes fresh chapatti, rice, and chips. She also sells fruit and sodas. Her shop is known at “Mama Japuony’s” by her regular customers due to the fact that her 9-year-old disabled son, Japuony (meaning “teacher”), is known in the community. Her older son, who is 18 years old, needs her financial help as he tries to finish secondary school (high school), and Frankline says that it is a challenge to pay his school fees.  She also has 5 children who are grown and out of the house.  

Frankline has faced many challenges in her life and in her business. Currently, the rising food prices in Kenya are affecting her profit margins. She cannot fully pass on the increased costs to her customers since they are unwilling to pay much more for her meals. This comes after Frankline rebuilt her business in early 2008. The post-election violence in Kisumu, at the end of 2007, resulted in her kiosk being burned to the ground. Still, she has her mind set on success. She takes some goods to sell wherever she goes, hoping to find business along the way.

loans.use: Goods for her food shop.

loans.name: Doljinjav

texts.en: Doljinjav is a 41-year-old businesswoman who lives with her family in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her three oldest children are university students and the youngest is a secondary school student. Doljinjav  operates a mobile retail trading business in her town. With the help of her husband, who is a driver, she uses the family car to travel throughout the countryside selling goods to local farmers. In addition to her mobile business, Doljinjav also purchases dairy products from the farmers to sell at the local market or sometimes in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Doljinjav started her business in 2000 and has achieved success. Since she started, her business capital has increased to more than five times its starting amount. She uses the business' profits to pay her children's university tuition, which is very expensive for the average rural family in Mongolia. Doljinjav is a very hard-working and open-minded person and says, "My dream is to one day have my own grocery store." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (approx. $690 USD) loan to purchase more goods for her mobile trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es: La señora Filomena es una cliente antigua D. la institución, muy responsable y puntual, tiene su tienda en su casa propia, su esposo trabaja con su movilidad ,sus hijos ya son independientes, su tienda ya tiene varios años y es muy conocida por la zona, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra D. cerveza, ya que los fines semana tiene pedidos D. este producto, por las fiestas que hay en la zona.
texts.en:
Filomena has been a client of the institution for a long time now; she is very responsible and punctual. She runs a grocery store from her home. Her husband works and her children are no longer dependent on their parents for support. Her store has been in operation for several years now and is very well known in the area. She will use the funds to purchase beer to have on stock since this is a highly requested item especially on the week-end due to the number of parties in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beer.

loans.name: Sombua

texts.en: Sombua B. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in the resturant and is requesting a loan to purchase more tables and chairs in her resturant.  Sombua is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a teacher . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her resturant  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more tables and chairs in her resturant

loans.name: Lumuli A Miriam Wagaba Group

texts.en: Miriam W. is 50 years old and is the cashier of her group. She is a single mother of six children, of which three go to school. Besides, she has three other dependents who are also schooling. She operates a retail business selling necessities such as salt, paraffin, sugar, soap and others. She has been running her business for four years. She is requesting a loan to improve her business. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as salt, paraffin, sugar, soap, etc.

loans.name: Errol

texts.en: Errol R. V. is 45 years old, is in a common-law relationship and has no children. He wants to buy merchandise that he can then sell in his small store. He has been in this business for many years and would like to expand. He also owns a farm, where he grows coffee. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR and he has not had any loans with any other banks in the past. He wants to grow his business and farm, to do this he has to buy clothing for resale and fertilizers for the farm land to improve the crop harvest. This loan will allow him to provide a safer home for any children that he might have in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies of store stock and fertilizer for coffee fields

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 53-year-old married man with four children. He has been working as a taxi driver for 20 years. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs.

Today, Mahmoud is asking for a loan of $1,000 to perform maintenance on his car to be able to continue his work properly.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es:
La señora Dionisia es socia del Banco Comunal “Juchuy Niño” ubicado en el  distrito de Capachica, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; tiene 43 años de edad, de estado civil casada con 5 hijos, vive en la comunidad de Yapura, no tuvo la ocasión de estudiar.

La señora esta trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde la fundación del Banco Comunal, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual le permitió incrementar su capital para su negocio de venta de pescado.

En la actualidad requiere de un nuevo préstamo de S/. 600.00 Nuevos soles, el cual le permitirá comprar redes para realizar la pesca artesanal, sus productos son comercializados en la plaza de Capachica.  También se dedica a la chacra.

Su mayor deseo es dar a sus hijos estudios para que sean profesionales y continuar trabajando.

A ella le  gustan  las reuniones, las charlas y los ahorros.
texts.en:
Dionicia is a member of the “Juchuy Niño” village bank, located in the Capachica district, Puno Province, Puno department. She is 43 years old, married with 5 children, and lives in the community of Yapura. She did not have the chance to study.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement (a Peruvian women's rights organization) since the founding of her village bank. Her initial loan was for PEN 300, which allowed her to increase her capital for her fish-selling business.

Now she needs a new loan of PEN 600, which will allow her to buy nets for traditional fishing. She sells her products in the city square of Capachica. She also works on a farm.

Her greatest wish is to continue working and to help her children study so that they can be professionals.

She enjoys the meetings, chats and savings at her bank.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nets for traditional fishing

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis N. is thirty-three years old. He is married to one wife and he is blessed with two children. 

He sells the ingredients for poultry feed, including silverfish, maize-brand, cotton cake (the solid matter that remains after oil has been pressed from cottonseeds), and seashells. He is using the loan to purchase more ingredients to sell. He has been in this business for over four years. His future plan and hope is to construct a big structure to house the poultry.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed ingredients to sell

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen F. R. es una  señora de 52 años de edad, la cual vive con su esposo y su hijo en una comunidad llamada El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Provincia de Cartago.  Es una pequeña comunidad rural de aproximadamente dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano. Sin embargo, varias veces al año el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que azotan la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. 

Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en la Zona Atlántica de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado, por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona y de esta forma evitar migrar.

Como parte de las respuestas a esa situación, desde hace dos años se instaló en la comunidad una planta de elaboración de quesos, propiedad de la Asociación de Productores de Leche de El Sauce, hecho que motivó a doña Carmen a iniciar en la producción de leche para luego venderla a esta planta. 

Doña Carmen desea obtener un micro crédito de ¢500,000 (quinientos mil colones) para comprar una vaca lechera y poder iniciar con su negocio ya que quiere ser una microempresaria exitosa y  así poder ayudar a sacar a su familia adelante esto es una de las cosas que la motiva a esforzarse y trabajar con mucho esmero. 

Doña Carmen es socia de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Carmen F. R. is 52 years old. She lives with her husband and their son in a community called El Sauce in Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Province of Cartago. This is a small rural community with around two thousand people. They are work producing milk and growing coffee. It has an irregular terrain and a lot of it is maintained as humid tropical forest. The community has traditional landscapes that mix with the tropical forest, with two nice lagoons, coffee plantations and milk factories. El Sauce is located about an hour and a half from Turrialba, the closest commercial center. However, several times a year, the road is closed due to the heavy rain in the area. This is without a doubt one of the main challenges of the community. When there was nothing to do in town, a lot of people decided to go to Turrialba for work or to banana farms in the Atlantic coast in Costa Rica. Right now, coffee and milk prices have improves, so the neighbors are looking for ways to invest their money in the area and avoid migrations. Due to this situation, two years ago, a cheese manufacturing company was installed in her community for the El Sauce’s Milk Producer’s Association. This motivated her to begin producing milk to resell it to the plant. This time, Carmen would like to get a ¢500.00 loan (five hundred colones) to purchase a milking cow and start her own business. She wants to be a successful entrepreneur to help her family. This motivates her to make sacrifices and work hard. Carmen is a member of the El Sauce Farmers Association, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be his ninth loan. She hopes to continue growing at a personal level and financial level. She also believes it’s important to mention that thanks to these type of organizations she is able to devote more time to productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a milking cow

loans.name: Señor De Huanca Group

texts.es:
Nuestros  socios pertenecen al banco comunal “SEÑOR D. HUANCA”, ubicado en la ciudad del Cusco en el distrito D. Huanchac.

Nuestros socios son un grupo D. 13 personas entre varones y mujeres, todos ellos amigos, nuestros socios son personas emprendedoras y ansiosos D. seguir creciendo más con el capital que mediante este medio se les otorga; los señores alternan sus diferentes actividades con el comercio, en este ameno grupo tenemos a profesores D. diferentes áreas D. un instituto, también a secretarías y a dos socios que compran y venden dólares, a una farmacéutica que tiene su botica cerca a la institución donD. laboran los otros socios, todos ellos solicitan el préstamo para reinvertir en  sus diferentes negocios y otro grupo para sus libros D. trabajo.

Nuestros socios agradecen y valoran el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y se comprometen en cumplir con el pago total D. sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members make up the “SEÑOR D. HUANCA” communal bank, which is located in the city of Cusco, Huanchac district. It is a group of 13 persons, both men and women, who are all friends and enterprising persons anxious to continue growing with the capital they get through this means. They each have different commercial activities. Among them are: teachers at an institute, secretaries, two members that do currency exchange, a pharmacist that has her drug store near the institution where the other members work. They all request funds to reinvest in their various businesses and another group to pay for their work-related books. The members appreciate and value the loan obtained and pledge to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The members will use the funds to buy ingredients and to reinvest in their various businesses.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel N. is thirty nine years old, is married and has two children. His business is located at Umoja 1, a residential area in Nairobi which is inhabited by middle-class people.

Samuel is involved in property management and serves the tenants in Umoja 1 estate. He has done this business for seven years and he is determined to make it grow. In fact, he wants to be a real estate owner in the future.

Samuel tries to manage customers who are not able to make payments to him as per their agreement; e.g. some clients are not able to pay rent which to Samuel is a challenge to his business.

Samuel is using his Kes 50,000 loan to buy office furniture to be able to run his business in the comfort of a nice office. Samuel also has a transport business. He is a very optimistic person.

loans.use: To buy office furniture

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucía es una mujer emprendedora de 32 años, está felizmente casada con Johan (32), con quien tiene 3 hermosos hijos: Danitza de 12, Leonardo de 10 y Amelí de 4 años. Está familia vive en su casa propia ubicada en la selva central del Perú.
Cada viernes, desde tempranas horas, Lucía instala su carpa frente a los servicios higiénicos públicos ubicados en la feria que se desarrolla en su ciudad. En este espacio vende ropa, pero a la vez que está encargada del cuidado e ingreso a los sanitarios, labor que desarrolla hace dos años con la ayuda de su hija mayor y de su hermana. A ella le gusta conocer nuevos clientes y recomendar las prendas de acuerdo al tamaño y la edad pero, confiesa que a veces cuando no vende lo que espera se siente decepcionada, sin embargo sigue luchando, pues siempre vende algo sin que haya perdido la inversión, por eso considera rentable sus actividades, pues vive cómodamente gracias a las ganancias que percibe.       
Para su futuro desea incrementar la cantidad de mercadería que vende, ya que no desea tener una tienda ni un lugar estable porque considera que en las ferias es donde se obtiene mayores beneficios económicos.

Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y se muestra muy entusiasmada con el trabajo que desempeña en su banco comunal, donde los integrantes son bastante activos y comprensivos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita planea comprar ropa interior e implementos de limpieza, artículos más solicitados por sus clientes.
texts.en:
Lucía is an enterprising woman who is 32 years old and is happily married to Johan (32), with whom she has 3 beautiful children: Danitza, 12, Leonardo, 10, and Amelí, who is 4. This family lives in their own home located in the central jungle of Peru. Every Friday, from the early hours, Lucía sets up her tent in front of the public toilets located in the market that takes place in her city. From this space she sells clothing, but at the same time she is responsible for the care and entrance to the toilets, work that she has been doing for 2 years with the help of her oldest daughter and her sister. She likes to get to know her customers, and to recommend the styles that are suitable for their size and age but she admits that at times, when she does not have the sales she hoped for, she feels disappointed. Nonetheless, she continues to strive; she always sells something without having lost her investment. For this reason, she regards this activity as profitable, and she lives comfortably thanks to the profits she earns. For the future she hopes to increase the quantity of merchandise that she sells; she does not wish to have a store or a fixed place of business, because she considers that the markets are the place where she can get the most economic benefits. This is her third loan from MFP, and she displays a lot of enthusiasm with the work that she carries out for the communal bank, where the members are quite active and supportive. With the money she requests now she plans to buy underwear and cleaning accessories, which are items that are in high demand from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase merchandise (buy underwear and cleaning accessories)

loans.name: José De La Concepción

texts.es:
El señor José H. se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de electrodomésticos en el mercado Mayoreo donde a diario ofrece los electrodomésticos tales como planchas, tostadoras, radios, licuadoras, cocinas, entre otros electrodomésticos.

Actualmente está solicitando un crédito el que será invertido directamente en la compra de dichos electrodomésticos para continuar ofreciéndolos en su establecimiento en el mercado.
texts.en:
Señor José H. works in his electrical appliance business in the Mayoreo marketin where he daily offers his wares such as irons, toasteres, radios, blenders, cookers and other appliances. He is seeking a loan which will be inverted in the purchase of more electrical appliances to continue offering them in his establishment in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase electrical appliances

loans.name: Gibrilla

texts.en: Gibrilla, 48, is a trader who sells men's clothes. He is married and has three school-aged children. Before that, he was a farmer. He sells at the Rogbaneh Road market centre in Makeni. Hard-working and dedicated, Gibrilla has been a trader for seven years. He wants  to expand his business and generate more income so as to be able to educate his children, run his household, and construct a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en: Teddy is married with school going children.  She rents a two roomed house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Teddy take care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Teddy owns a bar selling all types of drinks in Nakulabye. She works seven days a week. Teddy receives at least for 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on retail. Teddy has been in this business for long (ie seven years)and her business challenges include thieves and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for years and has been paying her loan promptly.  She wants to use this loan to increase on her stock by buying more crates of beer and jerry cans of local brew. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and own big bar . She joined MCDT because she could access loans easily..

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Noor Aqa Group

texts.en:
Marina is a member of the Noor Aqa group. She lives in the 11th district of Kabul. She is 37 years old and married with two children.

Marina has a business doing embroidery work and is quite popular in her neighborhood. People like her style of work and bring cloth to her so that she can create great designs in embroidery work for them.

Marina would like to receive a loan in order to purchase the required materials for her business to progress well and to increase. She hopes for a bright future for her children and to have a shop to work in, instead of working from her house. Marina is really happy about this effective loan process.

loans.use: purchase the required materials for her business

loans.name: Molia

texts.en:
Molia T. is 35 and married with 9 children (ages 2 - 24).  She is starting a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Molia needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Molia joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Molia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional young crops to raise

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena M. N. was born in the capital of Mocambique, Maputo city in 1977. She spent all her childhood there living with her parents and siblings. She studied until 10th grade, but she stopped because she got married and also because she did not have enough money to support her studies. She is married and has a young child, and she takes care of her parents who currently live with her. 

It is the first time she is asking for a loan with Hluvuku (Kiva's partner in Mozambique) or any other institution. She learned about them from her father's work colleague. She is asking for a loan to purchase zinc sheets, cement, paints and other construction materials to refurbish her home where and her entire family lives. She came to request her loan in person and when we went to take a picture of the family home, she was not available, so we show you a picture of her father, who will also benefit from the loan.

She is currently employed, helping at the till of a retail business. She learned the job from her boss five years ago. She makes 2,500 meticais a month and she is able to save about 1,000 meticais every month, so she is confident she will be able to repay the loan without problems.

Her dream in life is to see her parents' home in a good condition for all her family to live in.

loans.use: To purchase zinc sheets, cement, paints and other construction materials

loans.name: Xuraman

texts.en:
Xuraman, a 42-year-old single mother of two daughters, 12 and 16 years old, lives in Baku city where, for the past 10 years, she has been selling woman’s clothes in her small store. Xuraman buys the clothes in Lokbatan, a shopping center where items are sold at low cost, and unlike most of the retail stores in Baku, she sells clothes for bigger-sized women. Because of this, her shop has many loyal customers.

Xuraman is now seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to expand her store. She’d like to buy more clothes to sell and hopes that with additional income, she will be able to hire another employee so that she can spend more time with her children.

loans.use: To expand her store

loans.name: Fortaleza Group

texts.es:
Este grupo del Barrio Chaipé  se encuentra trabajando, cada una realiza una actividad productiva para generar ingreso de esa manera ayudar a su familia.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Maria quien se dedica a la confección de ropas para damas y caballeros.
Ella adquirio esta profesión muy joven, y actuamente se dedica a este trabajo de manera profesional, y realiza las confecciones sobre medidas. 
Hasta el  momento ella posee buena clientela ya que sus trabajos son muy apreciados por todos sus clientes por la calidad de sus prendas. 
Solicita el prestamo para la compra de materiales que ella utiliza en las confecciones como telas, hilos, botones, cierres, y otros.
texts.en:
This group from the Chaipé neighborhood is made up of members, each of whom engages in productive activities to help their families. Maria, one of the members, makes men’s and women’s clothing. She learned this skill when she was very young and now does this professionally by taking measurements. She has many customers because they appreciate the quality of her articles. She is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies, such as fabric, thread, buttons, fasteners, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Benitos

texts.es:
Benitos tiene 49 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa, sus suegros y a dos hijos que aun tiene a su cargo, el lugar donde reside se llama Tranca Sasape, la localidad es una zona rural que pertenece al distrito de Mórrope de la provincia de Lambayeque, se encuentra ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de dos años a brindar servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros en una mototaxi (vehículo conformado por una motocicleta que lleva anexada una cabina), el brinda su servicio cubriendo rutas que unen a su caserío con las zonas aledañas y gracias a esta actividad obtiene una fuente importante de ingresos con los cuales puede sostener a su familia.

El continuo uso brindado a su vehículo y el estado accidentado de los caminos de la zona han hecho que su mototaxi empiece a sufrir algunos daños que requieren de reparación urgente para garantizar su correcto funcionamiento, para repararlos, Benitos se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles, adicionalmente, con este dinero piensa tapizar el asiento de su vehículo para que sus pasajeros viajen cómodamente.

Benitos es una persona trabajadora y responsable, en la zona sus vecinos y conocidos le tienen mucha estima y le consideran una persona tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
Benitos is 49 years old and married. He lives with his wife, his mother-and-father-in law, and his two children. The children are still in his care. He lives in a place called Tranca Sasape. It is a rural area, which belongs to the Mórrope district in the Lambayeque province. It is located one hour from the city of Chiclayo. For over two years he has devoted himself to providing cargo and passenger transportation service in a “mototaxi” (a vehicle formed by a motorcycle that has a cabin attached to it). He provides service by covering routes that unite his settlement with the areas nearby. Thanks to this activity he gets an important source of income with which he is able to support his family. The continual use of his vehicle and the rugged state of the area’s roads have made his mototaxi start to have some problems. They require urgent repair in order to guarantee that they function correctly. Benitos is requesting, for the first time, a loan for 1,000 soles from Edpyme Alternativa in order to make the repairs. He will also use the money to upholster the seat in his vehicle so that his passengers travel comfortably. Benitos is a hard-working and responsible person. His neighbors and acquaintances in the area hold him in high esteem, and they consider him to be a peaceful and responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair and maintenace expenses for his mototaxi

loans.name: Sevjid

texts.en:
Sevjid T. is a 38 year-old widow who lives with her son in Uvs province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her son Tsend-Ayush attends a local middle school and helps his mother in her business on his vacation. 

Sevjid manages a flour trade business. She purchases flour at a wholesale price in Russia and sells it at retail in her town. She started her business in 2000 and has built a stable operation over the last few years. She works hard every day to grow her business and today her business revenues reach approximately 250,000 MNT. 

Sevjid continues to build on her business experience and hopes to expand in the near future. She says, "I hope to expand my business so that I can afford to provide for my son's education." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more flour for her business.

loans.use: To purchase flour to sell

loans.name: Lotovale

texts.en:
Lotovale T. is 45 and married with 5 children.  She owns a business venture planting and harvesting bananas for sale.  Lotovale has many years of experience in this business.  Lotovale needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Lotovale joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Lotovale's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Emerence

texts.en:
Emerence is 26 years old, married with one child of three months, and she takes care of two dependents.  Emerence makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop and this is her 2nd year in this business.  The business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Emerence needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.
